text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer. When we study a new language,

one challenge is acquiring vocabulary. We want 
to learn new words, but we struggle to remember

old ones. English can seem crazy 
at times because a single word

can have different meanings. Take "sweet," for 
example. "Sweet" can refer to a sugary taste,

like milk chocolate candy. "Sweet" can also 
describe someone who is kind. They have a sweet,

gentle nature. And in American English, "sweet" 
can also mean, "Nice! That's good." Or "Wow!

That's impressive." This is an informal meaning. 
It's something we'd use in casual conversation.

For example, if a friend got a new job, and 
it pays well, she has lots of vacation time,

and the company gives employees free tickets to 
professional sports events, my response: "Sweet!"

Now think of the word "mood." We often use 
this word to refer to how someone feels.

We can be in a good mood or a bad mood. If 
someone's mood constantly changes, we can call

them moody or say they have mood swings. Well, in 
grammar "mood" refers to the speaker's attitude

toward what is being said. Not all sources agree 
on what the moods are, but generally speaking,

we can ask what kinds of sentences do we 
use? What's the purpose of our communication?
We speak to state facts or truths.

When we use the indicative mood, we're certain 
about what we're saying. I make videos.

We also ask questions. Both our sentence 
structure and our intonation can change

when we use the interrogative mood. What kind 
of videos do you make? Are they educational?
We use questions to seek answers and confirmation,

but we can also use questions to make requests, 
as in, "Can you turn the volume down?"

An alternative is to issue a command. We do that 
with the imperative mood. Turn the volume down.

Sometimes we express that one event 
is dependent on another. That's when

we use the conditional mood. If you join me on 
Patreon, you'll get more interaction and support.

And then there's the subjunctive 
mood. Subjunctive verb forms

let us express wishes and possibilities. 
I wish you were all YouTube members.

The conditional mood can help us express 
hypothetical outcomes, and we often use

the modal verbs "could" and "would." I could play 
the piano better if I practiced more. I would play

better with more practice. So, the second example 
doesn't use "if," but it's an implied conditional.

In my understanding, two moods can be present 
together in the same sentence, for example,

a complex sentence. If I were less busy, I 
would play the piano for one or two hours a day.

So, we see the subjunctive in the first clause, 
the "if" clause. I'm expressing a wish. And the

main clause has the conditional mood; the 
outcome is dependent on some condition.

We may not use the subjunctive 
in every conversation,

but it's important that everyone gain some 
familiarity with subjunctive verb forms

because you will encounter them, so let's 
start our lesson on the subjunctive.

You've likely used the subjunctive in 
unreal conditionals about the present or

future. We use the subjunctive 
form "were" for all subjects.
If I were you, I'd stop worrying.
If she were here, she'd be laughing.
If he weren't so cautious, he'd take more risks.

You can use my playlist on conditionals to 
study these kinds of sentences with "if."

The subjunctive "were" is also used in wishes. I 
wish you were here. If only it weren't raining.

When used this way, the past form of 
"were" is sometimes called the past

subjunctive. But the subjunctive isn't used 
consistently in American English. It tends

to be used more in formal English, so you'll hear 
people use "was" even in hypothetical situations.

She talked to us as if she was the only 
one who knew the truth, but we all knew.

Here "as if" calls for the subjunctive because 
this is counterfactual, but not all speakers

will follow the pattern. They'll say "as 
if she was" rather than "as if she were."

I have an exclusive video on Patreon, by the 
way, that goes over the uses of "as if" and

"as though." It's one of the many perks you 
get when you join my membership program.

Let me ask you something about the kind of person 
you are. Do you try to influence others? Do you

feel that you have some control over what others 
do? Do you want to have that kind of influence?

Well, the subjunctive allows us to talk about our 
wishes as they relate to other people's actions.

First, we can use verbs that express some kind 
of necessity. Maybe my desire is weak, so I'm

only making a suggestion. Or maybe my desire for a 
certain outcome is strong, so I'm making a demand.

Compare these statements. I suggest that you 
review real and unreal conditional sentences.

I insist that you watch my playlist on 
conditionals if you have any lingering doubts.

"Suggest" and "insist" are the kinds of verbs that 
express a desire to push others towards action.

The subjunctive follows in a 
noun clause, a "that" clause.
Look at the verb form in the noun clause.

The so-called present subjunctive 
is the base form of the verb.

In these structures, we use the base verb 
for all subjects. I suggest that you review,

that he review, that we review. I insist that 
you watch, that she watch, that they watch.

The verbs in the main clause can change forms to 
reflect a past, present, or future time period,
but the subjunctive remains in the "that" clause.

I suggested that she review. I'm 
suggesting that everyone review.

I insisted that he continue. 
I'll insist that he continue.
Can you correct the mistakes in these sentences?

They recommended that we take a break. He's 
demanding that everyone call him "sir."
i'd like to propose that we hire outside help.

Note with some verbs, we have a choice 
how to structure our sentence. "Suggest"

and "recommend" can use the subjunctive in a 
"that" clause or a gerund as the direct object.

I suggest that you visit my website. 
I suggest visiting my website.

I recommend that you try my 
member-only tasks on YouTube.

I recommend trying my 
member-only tasks on YouTube.

A few verbs like "ask," "require," 
and "order" can use the subjunctive
or an infinitive after an object.

I ask that you be patient. 
I'm asking you to be patient.

The company requires that 
proof of vaccination be shown.

The company requires proof 
of vaccination to be shown.
That last sentence pair uses the passive voice.

The subjunctive has a passive 
form: be + the past participle.
How would you make this sentence passive?
We insist that respect be shown to co-workers.

The subjunctive can also have a 
negative form: not + the base verb.

It's essential that you 
not lose faith in yourself.

Ah, what did I use? The subjunctive is still in 
a "that" clause, but this noun clause follows

an adjective. It's essential that... 
The pattern holds for similar adjectives

that express a wish for someone to behave 
a certain way, to do a certain action.

It is essential that, it is important that, 
it is crucial that, it is desirable that...

These kinds of sentences sound formal. 
It is important that we remain strong.

In more relaxed conversation, we'll 
find alternatives with infinitives.

It's important to remain strong. It's 
important for everyone to remain strong.
Can you make these sentences less formal?

One. It's necessary to find a balance between 
serving others and taking care of ourselves. Two.

It's desirable to have enough material possessions 
without accumulating more than we need.

Three. It's crucial to gain enough 
sleep and consume enough calories.
Otherwise, your body won't function as it should.

Here's a final challenge. Can you give at least 
one piece of advice that leads to happiness or

success? Use the subjunctive two different 
ways. Here are my examples. It is essential

that you pursue something with passion. I strongly 
recommend that you pursue something with passion.

It's important that your 
life be filled with meaning.
I suggest that you fill your life with meaning.

All right. We'll end here. Please like and 
share the video if you found the lesson useful.
As always, thanks for watching and happy studies!
